Award.AwardTitle: STTR Phase II: SpiderRadio: Enabling Cognitive Dynamic Spectrum Access Wireless Communications
Award.AbstractNarration:
This Small Business Technology Transfer (STTR) Phase II project targets a practical dynamic spectrum management (DSM) architecture and a corresponding suite of innovative multi-layer algorithms, development of a DSM enabled multi-radio router and pilot trials for public safety communications. Dynamic spectrum management and access are two important areas of interest to wireless communications researchers, spectrum regulators, and international standardization bodies. DSM plays several important roles, including: (a) improving spectrum efficiency to alleviate the wireless spectrum crunch; (b) providing prioritized, inter-operable communications for first responders during emergencies; and (c) reducing cost for wireless access, and (d) improving the reliability and security of wireless communications. In this project, statistical estimation and decision algorithms are proposed for measurement driven real-time spectrum management at the physical/medium access control (PHY/MAC), network and application layers. Using agile software stack implementation and hardware integration a completely working DSM system will be demonstrated based on these ideas.

The broader impact/commercial potential of this project will be a better understanding of DSM related applications, regulatory policies and technical challenges in real-life mobile wireless networks. Impact on state-of-the-art technologies for resilient and interoperable public safety communications, especially during emergencies, is also expected. Findings from the pilot trials will contribute to the body of knowledge in interference mitigation, spectrum sharing, mobile data offloading and supporting reliable mobile multimedia applications. Taken together, these markets constitute a multi-billion dollar opportunity for DSM technologies.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Reliable public safety wireless communication during emergencies such as hurricanes is a critical need. In this project, we developed DSCast, an interactive and reliable datacasting system, to operate on TV white space as well as broadcast channels. Each option -- multiplexing on broadcast channels and utilizing TV white space -- has its advantages and disadvantages. Broadcast channels offer a much larger coverage area, but entail complicated negotiations with the broadcasters and are subject to more regulations. TV white space has a relatively smaller coverage area due to lower transmission power and antenna height, but the use of nomadic base stations can focus the coverage where it is needed. 

Cognitive wireless networking enables dynamic access of the available spectrum. DSCast’s dynamic spectrum access system encompasses knowledge about spectrum availability in space and time, smart networking protocols that exploit the available spectrum opportunistically, network stack implementation that inter-operates seamlessly with existing infrastructure and integration with hardware that for support high speeds.

Extensive drive tests in Monmouth County, New Jersey, indicate that DSCast is a promising technology with a path towards successful commercialization. Discussions with a number of potential partners and clients are ongoing. 

A number of graduate students were trained in this project leading to peer- reviewed publications. These students were also exposed to business development activities such as product R&D strategy and competitive analysis.
